feed.title: DATA 1301 - Fall 2020 - MW 4:00-5:20 - Microsoft Teams Virtual Room

entry.title: Final Exam
entry.content:
This exam covers all topics that we have discussed throughout the semester. The exam is open-lecture, open-homework and open-quiz. However, web-search, seeking help from your classmates or talking to or messaging them is absolutely forbidden and will have severe consequences.

Don’t forget to push your answers to your remote repository by the end of exam time. Push all your answers to exam/final/ folder in your Github project.


  1. Remember the Monte Hall problem that we discussed extensively in our lectures and in class. In the problem we discussed in class, we had only 3 doors, behind one of which there was a car while other doors had goats behind them. Now, suppose there are 10 doors instead of three, but there is still only a single car randomly hidden behind one of the doors. You pick a door to open, but before opening it, the host open another door for you, which he says, contains a goat. So, essentially he eliminates one door with a goat in it. Then, he asks you whether you want to switch the door you chose, to another one of remaining 8 doors. Would you increase your odds of winning the car by switching?

  2. Which of the following Git commands can add all the new and modified-existing files to the staging area? choose all that apply.

    (A) git add -A
    (B) git add --A
    (C) git add -all
    (D) git add --all
    (E) git add -u
    (F) git add .
    (G) git add .; git add -u
    (H) git add .; git add --u
    (I) git add -u; git add .
    (J) git add --u; git add .

  3. (A) What is the closest programming language to machine code (i.e., binary code)?

    (B) Does it need interpretation in order to become machine-comprehensible?

  4. Name a programming language ancestor of MATLAB and a programming language ancestor of Python.

  5. What types of uncertainty do exist according to the Frequentist school of thought? Can you reduce them to make you knowledge of the phenomena more accurate?

  6. Name the two fundamental properties of probability density functions (PDF).

  7. What is the probability of obtaining a value “1 and (2 or 3)” in a single experiment of throwing a die?

  8. Name the four major definitions of Probability.

  9. When data is scarce, which school of probability theory is the most useful for scientific inference?

  10. Name and briefly describe three different applications of Computational and Data Sciences.

  11. Show that the following identities hold,

    where the two arrow-up and arrow-down symbols represent the fundamental NAND and NOR operators,

  12. Name four major different color-scales for visualization purposes and describe briefly which one is good for what purposes?

  13. Is there any reason why one would advocate and avoid the application of red and green colors in a visualization?

Final Exam was originally published by Amir Shahmoradi at DATA 1301 - Fall 2020 - MW 4:00-5:20 - Microsoft Teams Virtual Room on December 09, 2020.

entry.title: Quiz 4: Statistics and data visualization
entry.content:
This quiz aims at testing your basic knowledge of (Bayesian) Probability Theory and Data Visualization concepts. Don’t forget to push your answers to your remote repository by the end of quiz time. Push all your answers to quiz/4/ folder in your Github project.


  1. Suppose you were participating in the The Monty Hall Problem that we discussed extensively in our class. You pick a door, but then the host blindly and randomly opens a door (other than what you chose), which subsequently luckily turns out to contain a goat (as opposed to prize: a car). Then the host asks you whether you would be interested in switching the door you chose with the only other door that is available and unopened. Would you switch your choice with the other remaining door? Would you improve your odds of winning the prize by switching the door? Explain our reasoning.

  2. What types of uncertainty do exist according to the Bayesian school of thought? Can you reduce them to make you knowledge of the phenomena more accurate?

  3. What types of uncertainty do exist according to the Frequentist school of thought? Can you reduce them to make you knowledge of the phenomena more accurate?

  4. Name the two fundamental properties of probability density functions (PDF).

  5. What Probability Density Function would likely best describe the statistics of the number of people going to Disneyland Park on any given day? Is this a discrete PDF or continuous?

  6. Name the most naturally-occurring distribution in Nature.

  7. What is the probability of obtaining a value 1 and 2 in a single experiment of throwing a die?

  8. What is the probability of obtaining a value 1 or 2 or larger than 5 in a single experiment of throwing a die?

  9. What distribution best describes the number of flowers per square feet of a garden, uniformly but randomly distributed across the entire garden?

  10. Does correlation mean causation? Explain with an example.

  11. Does correlation between two variables imply dependence between the two variables? Explain with an example.

  12. what are aesthetics in data visualization? Name a few aesthetics that can appear in a data visualization.

  13. Name the two major classes of aesthetics.

  14. Name the two major types of data and provide an example for each category.

  15. What is the common name for variables holding data?

  16. Provide examples of ordered and unordered data.

  17. What kinds of axes in a plot should be represented with the same units and grid size?

  18. Describe an example scenario in which transforming the axes of the plot results in better visualizations.

  19. What kind of data set can be best visualized in polar coordinates?

  20. Name four different color scales and explain their most appropriate usage.

Quiz 4: Statistics and data visualization was originally published by Amir Shahmoradi at DATA 1301 - Fall 2020 - MW 4:00-5:20 - Microsoft Teams Virtual Room on December 02, 2020.

entry.title: Homework 4: Probability Theory and Data Visualization
entry.content:
♣ Due Date: Wednesday Dec 2, 2020 4:00 PM (extended due to Thanksgiving break). This homework aims at giving you some experience with probability theory, and data visualization techniques.

  1. Name the two major types of uncertainty and explain which one(s) describe the type of uncertainty in Bayesian school of thought.
    Answer
    Aleatoric and Epistemic. Bayesian School of thought advocates Epistemic uncertainty as the sole source of lack of knowledge.
  2. Name the most naturally-occurring distribution in Nature.
    Answer
    Gaussian distribution.

  3. What is the probability of obtaining a value 1 and 2 in a single experiment of throwing a die?
    Answer
    0

  4. What is the probability of obtaining a value 1 or 2 or larger than 5 in a single experiment of throwing a die?
    Answer
    1/2

  5. What distribution best describes the number of flowers per square feet of a garden, uniformly but randomly distributed across the entire garden?
    Answer
    Poisson

  6. Does correlation mean causation? Explain with an example.
    Answer
    No. People who eat more chocolate tend to win more Nobel prizes. There is only correlation here, but most likely no causation.

  7. Does correlation between two variables imply dependence between the two variables? Explain with an example.
    Answer
    Yes. Thw weight of people correlates strongly with how much they eat. Weight depends on the food intake.

  8. what are aesthetics in data visualization? Name a few aesthetics that can appear in a data visualization.
    Answer
    All data visualizations map data values into quantifiable features of the resulting graphic. We refer to these features as aesthetics: position, shape, size, color, …

  9. Name the two major classes of aesthetics.
    Answer
    quantitative and qualitative.

  10. Name the two major types of data and provide an example for each category.
    Answer
    quantitative (e.g., the distribution of temperature on Earth) and qualitative (e.g., all animal species on Earth).

  11. What is the common name for variables holding qualitative data?
    Answer
    factor
  12. Provide examples of ordered and unordered data.
    Answer
    Ordered: The temperature of Earth over centuries.
    Unordered: All animal species on Earth.

  13. What kinds of axes in a plot should be represented with the same units and grid size?
    Answer
    The axes that represent data of the same nature and units (like temperature) should preferably have the same grid sizes.

  14. Describe an example scenario in which transforming the axes of the plot results in better visualizations.
    Answer
    For example, when there a few extreme values in data and lots of small values, like the distribution of wealth in the society.

  15. What kind of data set can be best visualized in polar coordinates?
    Answer
    Data that is periodic.

  16. Name four different color scales and explain their most appropriate usage.
    Answer
    1. Qualitative
    2. Sequential
    3. Diverging
    4. Accent

  17. What is wrong with the following visualization?

    Answer
    Age cannot be less than zero.

  18. Coordinates transformation in visualization.
    Answer
    See the question page.

  19. Best visualization coloring.
    Answer
    See the question page.

Homework 4: Probability Theory and Data Visualization was originally published by Amir Shahmoradi at DATA 1301 - Fall 2020 - MW 4:00-5:20 - Microsoft Teams Virtual Room on November 15, 2020.

entry.title: Quiz 3: Logic and probability theory
entry.content:
This quiz aims at testing your basic knowledge of Boolean Logic and Probability Theory. Don’t forget to push your answers to your remote repository by the end of quiz time. Push all your answers to quiz/3/ folder in your Github project.


  1. Name four major definitions of Probability.

  2. Which school(s) of probability theory define(s) probability as degree of confidence?

  3. Which school(s) of probability theory allow incorporation of expert (prior) knowledge in scientific inference?

  4. When data is scarce, which school of probability theory is the most useful for scientific inference?

  5. Name a prominent figure in each of the Frequentist and Bayesian schools of thought.

  6. NAND equivalence.

  7. Proof of Bayes Rule via Venn Diagrams.

Quiz 3: Logic and probability theory was originally published by Amir Shahmoradi at DATA 1301 - Fall 2020 - MW 4:00-5:20 - Microsoft Teams Virtual Room on November 02, 2020.

entry.title: Quiz 1: Version control system, programming history
entry.content:
This quiz aims at testing your basic knowledge of Version Control System and the history of programming. Don’t forget to push your answers to your remote repository by the end of quiz time. Push all your answers to quiz/1/ folder in your Github project.


  1. Which of the following Git commands can add all the new and modified-existing files to the staging area? choose all that apply.

    (A) git add -A
    (B) git add --A
    (C) git add -all
    (D) git add --all
    (E) git add -u
    (F) git add .
    (G) git add .; git add -u
    (H) git add .; git add --u
    (I) git add -u; git add .
    (J) git add --u; git add .

  2. Which of the following Git commands both stages and commits only modified and deleted files but NOT the new files added to the repository since the last commit. Choose all that apply.

    (A) git commit
    (B) git commit -a
    (C) git commit -am

  3. Write down the Git command that lists all Git commands for you.

  4. (A) What is the closest programming language to machine code (i.e., binary code)?

    (B) Does it need interpretation in order to become machine-comprehensible?

  5. (A) Name the oldest high-level programming language that is still in active daily use.

    (B) Approximately how many decades is it old? ($\pm15$ years is acceptable answer. the decade it was created is also an acceptable answer)

  6. (A) Name a second-generation programming language.

    (B) Which language-generation are Fortran, C, C++, MATLAB, Python, R?

  7. In what decades C, C++, and MATLAB/Python were created, respectively?

  8. Name an ancestor programming language of C.

  9. Name a programming language ancestor of C++.

  10. Name a programming language ancestor of MATLAB and a programming language ancestor of Python.

  11. How would you distinguish exponential behavior vs. power-law behavior (function) in a 2-dimensional plot?

Quiz 1: Version control system, programming history was originally published by Amir Shahmoradi at DATA 1301 - Fall 2020 - MW 4:00-5:20 - Microsoft Teams Virtual Room on September 28, 2020.

entry.title: Announcement 0: Student-professor connection day
entry.content:
On the first day of our class, we will try to get to know each other and I will attempt to describe my research work and educational background for you, as well as what we should expect from this course. Then I will present the results of the survey that I sent out to you a week ago to assess your programming knowledge, your favorite programming language, and the programming language that you would need for your research. Based on the survey results and your feedback in class, we will decide on the choice of language and the design of this course.

About me, Amir, the instructor

I am a physicist and researcher, and currently a faculty member at the Department of Physics as well as the Data Science Program in The College of Science at The University of Texas at Arlington. You can find more information about me, our group, and our research at cdslab.org. Here is a summary of my life in a few pictures:

I was introduced to the world of information and computer programming around 1991 by my father and elder brother. By the end of elementary school, I was so impressed with and knew enough about computer software to write a few simple computer games in QBasic programming language on our first family personal computer, IBM 386. Here is an example of how computer games looked liked 30 years ago.


I never imagined a day I would use computer programming for scientific purposes. Nevertheless, there has been almost no single day that I have not used scientific programming for my work and research, ever since I entered graduate school.

My research topics

The following are a few examples of what I do nowadays as part of my scientific research at UT Austin.

Theoretical Astrophysics

While my current focus of research is mathematical modelling of tumor growth and Monte Carlo samplers, I am and have been working in multiple branches of science and engineering for several years, from the subatomic world of elementary particles, to the microscopic world of biological macromolecules, to astrophysical phenomena occurring on the grandest scales of the observable Universe.

For several years of my research, I have been working on understanding Gamma-Ray Bursts (GRB) and their physics. Below is a movie of the moment a Short-duration GRB is generated from the merger of a binary Neutron star system.



Theoretical Biology, Bioinformatics

I have also worked for a few years in the field of bioinformatics and evolutionary biology. The overarching goal in the field of protein bioinformatics and biophysics is to understand how proteins fold into their unique structure, and what determines the stability of the protein 3D structure.






One of the workhorses of this field, is therefore molecular dynamic simulation to probe the dynamics of proteins and their interactions with other molecules. The following is a 1.5ns molecular dynamics simulation of Human Influenza H1 Hemagglutinin protein (1RD8, chains AB).


Petroleum Engineering


Computational Oncology

What you see in the figures below, is a representation of the growth of Glioblastoma tumor cells in a Rat’s brain over time.








The temporal evolution of the growth of Glioma tumor in rat






Monte Carlo Simulation and Integration Methods

One of the fields on which my research is currently focused, is developing Monte Carlo optimizer/sampler and integrator algorithms for Bayesian inverse problems.

Development of Monte Carlo sampling algorithms

Below you see example animations of two Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) samplers, both of which sample a double Gaussian-peak function, but with different MCMC sampling parameters.



Development of Monte Carlo integration algorithms















Biomedical Data Science




Announcement 0: Student-professor connection day was originally published by Amir Shahmoradi at DATA 1301 - Fall 2020 - MW 4:00-5:20 - Microsoft Teams Virtual Room on August 26, 2020.
